required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Needle-Free Jet Injection of Lidocaine During Lumbar Puncture
clinical_study.official_title: Needle-Free Jet Injection of Lidocaine for Local Anesthesia During Lumbar Puncture: A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
Background: The J-Tip Device allows an intradermal needle-free jet injection of 1% buffered lidocaine. This study compares needle-free jet injection of lidocaine to saline in reducing pain prior to lumbar puncture in infants.
Methods: Randomized, double-blinded, placebo controlled trial involving infants, less than 3 months of age, presenting to the emergency department meeting clinical criteria for a lumbar puncture. All patients were administered the J-tip and randomized to either treatment with 1% lidocaine or an equivalent amount of sterile normal saline prior to lumbar puncture.

detailed_description.textblock:
Background: Lumbar puncture is an essential procedure in the emergency department for the evaluation of meningitis. Subcutaneous injection of lidocaine prior to lumbar puncture for local anesthesia is not a pain free procedure. The J-Tip Device allows an intradermal needle-free jet injection of 1% buffered lidocaine. This study compares needle-free jet injection of lidocaine to saline in reducing pain prior to lumbar puncture in infants.
Methods: Randomized, double-blinded, placebo controlled trial involving infants, less than 3 months of age, presenting to the emergency department meeting clinical criteria for a lumbar puncture. All patients were administered the J-tip and randomized to either treatment with 1% lidocaine or an equivalent amount of sterile normal saline prior to lumbar puncture. Vital signs were recorded during the procedure. Facial expressions as well as crying times were video recorded from start to finish. Independent reviewers assigned pain scores based on the validated Neonatal Facial Coding System with possible scores ranging from 0-5.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Caregiver, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Pain, Measured as Units on a Scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: on average the first hour in emergency department at 4 time points during entire lumbar puncture procedure.
primary_outcome.description: Pain scores at time of needle insertion using neonatal facial coding score. The scale has five components; cry, brow bulge, eye squeeze; nasolabial fold and open month. Each component is either present or absent, with a value of 0 or 1 given. Minimum score of 0 and a maximum score of 5 possible

secondary_outcome.time_frame: On average the first hour in the emergency department; from needle stick to end of lumbar puncture
secondary_outcome.description: cry video recorded and measured after needle stick until pt stopped crying

secondary_outcome.time_frame: On average the first hour in the emergency department, at 4 time points during lumbar puncture procedure.

arm_group.description: needleless injection of buffered lidocaine prior to lumbar puncture
needleless injection of normal saline prior to lumbar puncture

intervention.description: All patients were administered the J-tip and randomized to either treatment with 1% lidocaine or an equivalent amount of sterile normal saline prior to lumbar puncture. Vital signs were recorded during the procedure. Facial expressions were video recorded
intervention.other_name: jtip is the brand name for 1% buffered lidocaine needleless injection

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- fever in infants less than 3 months
Exclusion Criteria:
- toxic appearance, altered level of consciousness, age greater than 3 months or less than 4kg of weight

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
